metadata.subject: biology
metadata.dotPoint: The general role of enzymes and coenzymes in facilitating steps in photosynthesis and cellular respiration

concepts.name: catalyst function
concepts.formula: Catalysts speed up reactions by lowering activation energy without being consumed or permanently changed
concepts.correct: Correct! Catalysts lower the activation energy barrier, allowing reactions to proceed faster or under milder conditions, while remaining unchanged and reusable.

wrong.error: You thought catalysts provide energy for reactions. They lower the energy BARRIER, not provide energy.
wrong.fix: Catalysts reduce activation energy (the 'hump' to get over). They don't add energy; they make less energy needed.
wrong.action: Think of a catalyst as lowering a hill, not pushing you over it. Less climbing needed.

wrong.error: You thought catalysts are used up in reactions. Catalysts are not consumed and can be reused.
wrong.fix: Catalysts participate in reactions but are regenerated. One catalyst molecule can catalyse many reactions.
wrong.action: Catalysts are like matchmakers—they help reactions happen but walk away unchanged.

wrong.error: You confused catalysts with reactants. Catalysts facilitate reactions but are not converted into products.
wrong.fix: Reactants → products (consumed). Catalysts → catalysts (unchanged). Different roles in reactions.
wrong.action: Catalysts don't appear in the net equation because they're the same before and after.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding that catalysts lower activation energy without being consumed.
persistent.action: Draw an energy diagram showing: uncatalysed (high peak) vs catalysed (lower peak), same start and end points.

concepts.name: activation energy
concepts.formula: Activation energy is the minimum energy required for a reaction to proceed; catalysts lower this barrier
concepts.correct: Correct! Activation energy is the energy threshold that must be overcome for reactants to convert to products. Catalysts provide an alternative pathway with a lower activation energy.

wrong.error: You confused activation energy with the energy released by a reaction. They're different concepts.
wrong.fix: Activation energy = barrier to START the reaction. Energy released = difference between reactants and products.
wrong.action: Activation energy is like the push needed to start a boulder rolling. Energy released is how far it rolls down.

wrong.error: You thought lowering activation energy changes the products. It only affects HOW FAST products form.
wrong.fix: Catalysts change reaction RATE, not the final products. Same destination, faster journey.
wrong.action: A catalyst is a shortcut—you get to the same place faster, but it's still the same place.

wrong.error: You thought all reactions have the same activation energy. Different reactions have different barriers.
wrong.fix: Each reaction has its own activation energy. Some reactions need lots of energy to start; others need very little.
wrong.action: Burning paper has low activation energy (starts easily). Breaking diamond has high activation energy (very hard to start).

persistent.gap: You're confusing activation energy with other energy concepts.
persistent.action: Label an energy diagram: activation energy (peak height above reactants), energy change (difference between reactants and products).

concepts.name: enzyme structure
concepts.formula: Enzymes are globular proteins with an active site that binds specific substrates based on shape and chemistry
concepts.correct: Correct! Enzymes are proteins folded into specific 3D shapes. The active site is a pocket that binds substrates through complementary shape and chemical properties.

wrong.error: You thought enzymes are made of carbohydrates or lipids. Enzymes are proteins (amino acid chains).
wrong.fix: Enzymes are globular proteins. Their catalytic function depends on their precise 3D shape from protein folding.
wrong.action: Enzyme = protein = amino acids. The tertiary structure creates the active site shape.

wrong.error: You confused the active site with the whole enzyme. The active site is just a small region.
wrong.fix: The active site is a specific pocket or cleft in the enzyme where substrate binding and catalysis occur.
wrong.action: The enzyme is like a hand; the active site is like the grip between fingers. Small part of the whole.

wrong.error: You thought any substrate can fit any enzyme. Enzymes are highly specific for their substrates.
wrong.fix: Enzymes show specificity—each enzyme typically catalyses only one reaction with one substrate (or a few similar ones).
wrong.action: Like a lock and key: one enzyme fits one substrate. Shape AND chemistry must match.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding enzyme structure and specificity.
persistent.action: Draw an enzyme showing: globular shape, small active site pocket, substrate fitting into the pocket.

concepts.name: enzyme-substrate complex
concepts.formula: Substrates bind to the active site forming an enzyme-substrate complex; products are released and the enzyme is reused
concepts.correct: Correct! The substrate binds to the active site, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. Catalysis occurs, products are released, and the enzyme is free to bind another substrate.

wrong.error: You thought the enzyme permanently binds the substrate. The complex is temporary—products are released.
wrong.fix: E + S → ES complex → E + P. The enzyme binds, catalyses, releases products, and is recycled.
wrong.action: Enzymes are like revolving doors—substrates enter, products exit, enzyme keeps spinning.

wrong.error: You confused the substrate with the product. Substrate = input; product = output after catalysis.
wrong.fix: Substrate is what ENTERS the active site. Product is what LEAVES after the reaction.
wrong.action: Substrate → (enzyme action) → Product. The enzyme transforms substrate into product.

wrong.error: You thought the enzyme is changed by the reaction. Enzymes are not altered—they're catalysts.
wrong.fix: After releasing the product, the enzyme returns to its original state, ready for another substrate.
wrong.action: Enzyme before = enzyme after. That's what makes it a catalyst—it's regenerated.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the enzyme catalytic cycle.
persistent.action: Draw the cycle: E + S → ES → EP → E + P → E binds new S → repeat.

concepts.name: induced fit
concepts.formula: The induced fit model states that the active site changes shape to better accommodate the substrate upon binding
concepts.correct: Correct! Unlike the rigid lock-and-key model, induced fit proposes that the active site moulds around the substrate, optimising binding and potentially straining substrate bonds.

wrong.error: You confused induced fit with lock-and-key. Lock-and-key = rigid fit; induced fit = flexible adjustment.
wrong.fix: Lock-and-key: perfect pre-existing fit. Induced fit: active site adjusts shape when substrate binds.
wrong.action: Lock-and-key = hard plastic mould. Induced fit = flexible glove that adjusts to the hand.

wrong.error: You thought induced fit means any substrate can bind. The enzyme still has specificity—just with flexibility.
wrong.fix: Induced fit allows better binding of the correct substrate. Wrong substrates still won't fit properly.
wrong.action: The glove adjusts to the right hand, not to a foot. Flexibility enhances specificity, doesn't eliminate it.

wrong.error: You thought the conformational change is permanent. The enzyme returns to its original shape after product release.
wrong.fix: Induced fit is temporary: bind → shape change → catalysis → release → shape returns. Fully reversible.
wrong.action: The enzyme 'relaxes' back to its resting shape after each catalytic cycle.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding how induced fit differs from lock-and-key.
persistent.action: Draw both models: lock-and-key (rigid shapes fit perfectly) vs induced fit (active site wraps around substrate).

concepts.name: coenzyme function
concepts.formula: Coenzymes are organic molecules that assist enzymes by transferring chemical groups or electrons between reactions
concepts.correct: Correct! Coenzymes are helper molecules that participate in reactions by carrying chemical groups (like phosphates or electrons) from one enzyme to another.

wrong.error: You confused coenzymes with enzymes. Enzymes are proteins; coenzymes are small organic helper molecules.
wrong.fix: Enzyme = protein catalyst. Coenzyme = non-protein helper that carries groups between enzymes.
wrong.action: Enzymes do the work; coenzymes carry supplies. Different molecules, complementary roles.

wrong.error: You thought coenzymes are used once. Coenzymes cycle between loaded and unloaded states.
wrong.fix: Coenzymes are recycled: they pick up a group from one reaction and deliver it to another, then go back for more.
wrong.action: Think of coenzymes as delivery trucks—they load, deliver, return empty, reload, repeat.

wrong.error: You confused coenzymes with cofactors. Coenzymes are organic; cofactors include inorganic ions like Mg2+.
wrong.fix: Coenzyme = organic molecule (often vitamin-derived). Cofactor = broader term including metal ions and coenzymes.
wrong.action: All coenzymes are cofactors, but not all cofactors are coenzymes. Coenzyme = organic specifically.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing coenzymes from enzymes and understanding their shuttle function.
persistent.action: Draw a coenzyme shuttling between two enzymes: pick up group at enzyme A, deliver to enzyme B, return.

concepts.name: ATP structure and function
concepts.formula: ATP stores energy in its phosphate bonds; hydrolysis to ADP + Pi releases energy for cellular work
concepts.correct: Correct! ATP (adenosine triphosphate) has three phosphate groups. Breaking the bond to the terminal phosphate releases energy that powers cellular processes.

wrong.error: You thought ATP is a long-term energy store. ATP is immediate energy; glucose/fat are long-term stores.
wrong.fix: ATP = ready-to-use energy (like cash). Glucose/fat = stored energy (like savings account).
wrong.action: Cells maintain small ATP pools that turn over rapidly. For storage, they make glucose, glycogen, or fat.

wrong.error: You confused ATP synthesis with ATP hydrolysis. Synthesis = making ATP; hydrolysis = breaking it for energy.
wrong.fix: ADP + Pi + energy → ATP (synthesis, stores energy). ATP → ADP + Pi + energy (hydrolysis, releases energy).
wrong.action: Making ATP = charging a battery. Using ATP = discharging the battery.

wrong.error: You thought the adenosine part stores the energy. The energy is in the phosphate bonds, not the adenosine.
wrong.fix: The terminal phosphate bonds are 'high energy'—breaking them releases energy. Adenosine is just the base structure.
wrong.action: Adenosine = the handle. Phosphates = the energy packets. Remove phosphates = release energy.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding ATP as the cell's energy currency.
persistent.action: Draw ATP structure: adenosine + 3 phosphates. Show hydrolysis releasing the terminal phosphate + energy.

concepts.name: hydrogen carriers
concepts.formula: Hydrogen carriers (NAD+, FAD, NADP+) transport protons and electrons between metabolic reactions
concepts.correct: Correct! Hydrogen carriers accept electrons and protons (hydrogen) from oxidation reactions, becoming reduced (NADH, FADH2, NADPH), then deliver them to reduction reactions.

wrong.error: You confused hydrogen carriers with ATP. ATP carries energy via phosphates; hydrogen carriers carry electrons/protons.
wrong.fix: ATP = energy carrier (phosphate transfer). Hydrogen carriers = electron/proton carriers (redox reactions).
wrong.action: Different 'currencies': ATP for direct energy, hydrogen carriers for reducing power and electron transport.

wrong.error: You thought 'hydrogen carrier' means they carry H2 gas. They carry H as protons (H+) and electrons (e-).
wrong.fix: Hydrogen = proton + electron. Carriers accept these from substrates being oxidised, not H2 gas.
wrong.action: When a substrate loses hydrogen (is oxidised), the carrier gains it (is reduced). NAD+ → NADH.

wrong.error: You confused oxidised and reduced forms. NAD+ is oxidised (empty); NADH is reduced (loaded with hydrogen).
wrong.fix: Oxidised = ready to accept (NAD+, FAD, NADP+). Reduced = carrying hydrogen (NADH, FADH2, NADPH).
wrong.action: OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain. Carriers GAIN hydrogen when reduced.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding hydrogen carriers as electron/proton shuttles.
persistent.action: Write the conversion: NAD+ + 2H → NADH + H+. Label which form is oxidised and which is reduced.

catalysts.title: What Are Catalysts?
catalysts.instructions: Learn the basic properties of catalysts and how they work.

sentences.text: A catalyst is a substance that enables a chemical reaction to proceed at a {{d1}} rate by lowering the {{d2}} required for the reaction.

d2.tooltip: The energy barrier that must be overcome

sentences.text: Catalysts are not {{d1}} or {{d2}} by the reactions they influence, so they can be reused many times.

d1.tooltip: Catalysts remain unchanged after the reaction

sentences.text: Because catalysts can be reused, they occur at relatively {{d1}} levels in cells compared to the {{d2}} they process.

d1.tooltip: Small amounts of catalyst are needed

d2.tooltip: The molecules that catalysts act upon

enzymes.title: Enzymes as Biological Catalysts
enzymes.instructions: Understand the structure and function of enzymes.

sentences.text: Enzymes are {{d1}} proteins which act as biological catalysts, speeding up reactions by lowering the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Enzymes have a compact, spherical shape

d2.tooltip: What enzymes reduce to speed reactions

sentences.text: Every enzyme has a specific region called the {{d1}} where the {{d2}} binds to form an enzyme-substrate complex.

d2.tooltip: The molecule that the enzyme acts upon

sentences.text: The active site and substrate complement each other in terms of both {{d1}} and {{d2}} properties, such as opposite charges.

d1.tooltip: The 3D fit between enzyme and substrate

coenzymes.title: Coenzymes and ATP
coenzymes.instructions: Learn about helper molecules that assist enzymes.

sentences.text: A {{d1}} is a complex organic molecule that is required for an enzyme's metabolic activity, assisting with catalysis.

d1.tooltip: An organic helper molecule for enzymes

sentences.text: Coenzymes cycle between two states: a {{d1}} form that can be used and an {{d2}} form, similar to a charged or expended battery.

d2.tooltip: Ready to pick up more cargo

sentences.text: {{d1}} (adenosine triphosphate) is a high energy molecule that contains three {{d2}} groups which store potential energy in their bonds.

carriers.title: Hydrogen Carriers
carriers.instructions: Understand how hydrogen carriers transport electrons and protons.

sentences.text: Hydrogen carriers are coenzymes that transport {{d1}} and {{d2}} between chemical reactions, functioning like a chemical taxi.
Hydrogen carriers are loaded by {{d1}} reactions (becoming reduced) and unloaded in {{d2}} reactions (becoming oxidised).
Examples of hydrogen carriers include {{d1}} and FADH2 (used by mitochondria), as well as {{d2}} (used by chloroplasts).

d1.tooltip: A hydrogen carrier used in respiration

d2.tooltip: A hydrogen carrier used in photosynthesis

catalysts.title: Enzyme Mechanism
catalysts.instructions: Explore how enzymes lower activation energy.

sentences.text: When a substrate binds to the active site, the enzyme may undergo a {{d1}} change in shape to better fit the substrate, as described by the {{d2}} model.

d2.tooltip: The model where enzyme shape adjusts

sentences.text: This conformational change may {{d1}} and destabilise the bonds in the substrate, hence lowering the {{d2}} for the reaction.

d1.tooltip: Put strain on the substrate bonds

d2.tooltip: The energy barrier for the reaction

sentences.text: After the substrate is converted into product, the product will {{d1}} from the enzyme, allowing the enzyme to be {{d2}}.

enzymes.title: Enzyme Specificity
enzymes.instructions: Understand why enzymes are specific for their substrates.

sentences.text: The {{d1}} model proposes that the enzyme and substrate fit together like a key in a lock, with pre-existing complementary shapes.

d1.tooltip: The rigid model of enzyme-substrate binding

sentences.text: Enzyme reactions typically occur in {{d1}} solutions because this reflects the internal conditions of an organism like the {{d2}}.
Sometimes an enzyme may be {{d1}} in position, such as when it is {{d2}}-bound, which localises the reaction to a particular site.

coenzymes.title: ATP as Energy Currency
coenzymes.instructions: Explore how ATP stores and releases energy.

sentences.text: When ATP is {{d1}} to form ADP and Pi (inorganic phosphate), the energy stored in the phosphate bond is {{d2}} for use by the cell.
ATP can be produced directly from ADP and Pi via {{d1}}-level phosphorylation, or indirectly via {{d2}} phosphorylation using hydrogen carriers.

d1.tooltip: Direct transfer of phosphate from a substrate

sentences.text: ATP functions as an {{d1}} source of power for cell processes, transferring {{d2}} from catabolic to anabolic reactions.

carriers.title: Hydrogen Carriers in Metabolism
carriers.instructions: Understand the roles of different hydrogen carriers.

sentences.text: The protons and electrons carried by hydrogen carriers can be used to synthesise organic macromolecules via {{d1}} reactions like photosynthesis.
Hydrogen carriers also function as intermediate {{d1}} sources via their energised electrons and can be used to make {{d2}} through the electron transport chain.
NAD+ accepts hydrogen to become {{d1}}, while FAD accepts hydrogen to become {{d2}}, with both carriers used in cellular respiration.

catalysts.title: Catalysis in Metabolic Pathways
catalysts.instructions: Analyse how enzymes work together in metabolic pathways.

sentences.text: In metabolic pathways, each step is catalysed by a {{d1}} enzyme, allowing for precise {{d2}} at multiple points in the pathway.

d1.tooltip: Each step has its own enzyme

sentences.text: The product of one enzymatic reaction becomes the {{d1}} for the next enzyme, creating a sequential {{d2}} of reactions.
This multi-enzyme system allows cells to fine-tune metabolic {{d1}} by regulating individual enzymes rather than the entire {{d2}}.

enzymes.title: Enzyme Kinetics
enzymes.instructions: Evaluate factors affecting enzyme reaction rates.

sentences.text: The rate of enzyme catalysis depends on successful {{d1}} between enzyme and substrate, which increases with higher {{d2}} energy.
Increasing temperature initially {{d1}} enzyme activity by increasing molecular motion, but excessive heat causes {{d2}}.
The rate of enzyme activity can also be affected by substrate {{d1}}, with activity levelling off when all enzymes are {{d2}} with substrate.

coenzymes.title: Energy Coupling
coenzymes.instructions: Analyse how ATP couples energy-releasing and energy-requiring reactions.

sentences.text: ATP couples {{d1}} reactions (which release energy) with {{d2}} reactions (which require energy), enabling cellular work.
The hydrolysis of ATP is often {{d1}} to unfavourable reactions, with the energy released driving the otherwise {{d2}} reaction forward.

d2.tooltip: Reactions that wouldn't occur on their own

sentences.text: The ATP/ADP ratio in cells reflects the current {{d1}} status, with high ATP indicating energy {{d2}} and high ADP indicating energy {{d3}}.

carriers.title: Electron Transport
carriers.instructions: Evaluate how hydrogen carriers power ATP synthesis.

sentences.text: The electrons carried by NADH and FADH2 have {{d1}} energy than those carried by NADPH, reflecting their different metabolic {{d2}}.
NADH from glycolysis and the Krebs cycle delivers electrons to the {{d1}} transport chain, ultimately producing {{d2}} through chemiosmosis.
NADPH from the light reactions provides {{d1}} power for the Calvin cycle, enabling the {{d2}} of carbon dioxide into glucose.
